Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
Has anyone read this article?

https://blog.ethereum.org/2015/02/14/subjectivity-exploitability-tradeoff/

I wonder if you can use it to counter arguments against dPoW? Or if it eludes to something which can be built into Komodo?

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
@passcombo.com ğŸ´â˜ ğŸ‹ "serving as fiat market maker can bring nice profit due to spread, but the problem I see is how to make such market maker not manipulate, so that a fiat-pegged asset would be stable, kind of special reward for stabilization weould need to be inveted, that would be good enough for big fiat players"

This is what the article I posted above alludes to. Basically the fiat exchange rate is a Schelling Point which can be translated into a blockchain using the design in the article.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
https://www.reddit.com/r/CryptoTechnology/comments/a7azz8/comment/ec6ty9l

I got turned around at some point in this conversation. I'm not looking for holes or anything, it's fine with me either way, I'm just wondering, is the theoretical attack he's talking about a way for a majority of notaries to double spend after notarization, or is the attack he's talking about only before notarization? I don't see a problem either way, to be clear.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
Here's the attack you mention:  "If what you are saying that there are some theoretically unlikely (but not 100% impossible) scenarios where the majority of notaries in conjunction with significant hashrate can conduct attacks that are harder to do than normal and further identify the attacker directly, then maybe we can agree to that."

Is this after notarization? It seems so.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: Even so, after conversations with the fine folk here, I agree that this attack is harder to do than attacking Bitcoin itself, but if we can find ways to improve on Bitcoin, that would be killer.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: To be clear, at this point, I'm a Komodo believer, I don't need any more convincing. I just want to learn and discuss.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Not sure what you mean by `Is this after notarization? It seems so.`

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: The attack Taek or however you spell it is talking about.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: his proposed attack would be majority of notaries and majority of hashrate colluding to notarize a chian that was not public

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: Yep Edit: I sounded like I knew what you were saying here, but you helped me understand.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: majority of notaries is an understatement, more like supermajority as that can't pick and choose who they will notarize with

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: It's my understanding that a majority of notaries can remove other notaries, is that right? I don't know the complete details of that process.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: It's supposed to be if a notary isn't performing their duties.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: They technically could but there is no precedence for this

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content:
But what I'm getting at is, it's a way to double spend, right? Where he says this:

> This is precisely how double spends happen. There's one fork where the exchange got the money and the money confirmed, and there's another fork where the exchange didn't get the money. Notary nodes split the network and fork the exchange onto a smaller-work, not widely accepted fork where they got the money, while the rest of the network continues forward on the fork where the exchange doesn't have the money.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: Does this bypass the dPoW-conf protection or not? EDIT: Nevermind, you said the new chain gets notarized, so it does bypass any protection. I believe I get it.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: Can't stress enough, that I still believe this is a harder attack than even Bitcoin, with its mining pools. I just want to make sure I understand the attack vector, however unlikely it is.

Author: garbonzo607#4659
Content: I think I get it now.
